Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Azure Search] Point Gallery to preview service" (#7632) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Closed issue "iconUrl warning appears for packages with no icon at all" (#7605) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Describe the bug

For a package with no `<iconUrl>`, I get an `<iconUrl>` warning.

### To Reproduce

1. Make a package with no `<iconUrl>`.
2. Drop it in the gallery upload UI.

### Expected behavior
No warning.

### Screenshots

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94054/66249103-a616fd80-e6e3-11e9-8d9b-b853e2bcbacf.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94054/66249107-b333ec80-e6e3-11e9-992e-4d3468426416.png)

/cc @agr

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Azure Search] Move service index to Azure Search for autocomplete" (#7401) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
DEV deployment: https://nuget.visualstudio.com/NuGetBuild/_build/results?buildId=63170
DEV China deployment: https://nuget.visualstudio.com/NuGetBuild/_build/results?buildId=63240
INT deployment: https://nuget.visualstudio.com/NuGetBuild/_build/results?buildId=63175
PROD deployment: https://nuget.visualstudio.com/NuGetBuild/_build/results?buildId=63185
PROD China deployment: https://nuget.visualstudio.com/NuGetBuild/_build/results?buildId=63271

### App Insights verification query (Azure Search):

```
requests
| where name == "GET Search/AutocompleteAsync"
| extend Region = toupper(substring(cloud_RoleName, strlen("nuget-prod-"), strlen(cloud_RoleName)-strlen("nuget-prod-azuresearch-")))
| summarize count() by bin(timestamp, 30m), Region
| render barchart kind=stacked 
```

### App Insights verification query (Legacy Search):

```
requests
| where timestamp > ago(90d)
| where name in ("GET /search/diag", "GET /search/query", "GET /query", "GET /autocomplete")
| extend dId = tostring(customDimensions.DeploymentId)
| extend DeploymentName =
  iff(dId == "a755594844164679a1ca264946f81f18" or dId == "233d868eef7b47ddacbc138a147a50c3", "PROD USNC",
     iff(dId == "86b2d4f718ee498996291ab94a08febf" or dId == "c4e86a9343a44b7ba14593a720e5c13c", "PROD USSC",
       iff(dId == "fe4df56377be435a97eded74a7529f98" or dId == "d293fb80632a41cbbfc535e9adeb5c2c", "PROD EA",
         iff(dId == "15493afe371f43e99924731983887688" or dId == "e3f92c47a56342a0bd36f3f971700184", "PROD SEA", "Unknown")
       )
     )
  )
| extend DeploymentAndRequestNames = strcat(DeploymentName, " ", name) 
| summarize count() by bin(timestamp, 1d), DeploymentAndRequestNames, DeploymentName, name
| order by count_ desc
| render barchart kind=stacked 
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[GitHub Indexer] Add run duration telemetry" (#7625) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
See https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Jobs/pull/813

Application Insights verification queries:

```
customMetrics
| where cloud_RoleName == "NuGet.Jobs.GitHubIndexer"
| where name == "GitHubIndexer.RunDurationSeconds" 
| order by timestamp desc
```

```
traces
| where cloud_RoleName == "NuGet.Jobs.GitHubIndexer"
| where customDimensions.MessageTemplate == "Finished indexing GitHub repositories in {TotalSeconds} seconds." 
  or customDimensions.MessageTemplate == "The job has succeeded. Sleeping for {Duration} before terminating." 
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "How to install Main NuGet and dependent NuGet with same FrameWork version." (#8665) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
When i install custom nuget package **packages.aspnet.mvc5** in aspnet application with targetFramework 4.6 , The Main package(packages.aspnet.mvc5) dll referred 4.5 Framework. But the dependency of main package **compression.base**(Independent Nuget) dll referred from 4.6 targetframework instead of 4.5 Framework. Due to his bindig redirect entry added in webconfig file. Example,
```
        **<dependentAssembly>
    <assemblyIdentity name="compression.base" publicKeyToken="7285hf33478get3a" 
    culture="neutral" />
     <bindingRedirect oldVersion="0.0.0.0-11.3450.0.14" newVersion="11.3460.0.14" />
    </dependentAssembly>**
```

How to resolve this issue, while insalling the NuGet?

We have tested by , shipping the dependent package(compression.base) dll with Main Package instead of using dependent package. While used like that, it refers all dll from 4.5 Framework. But when uninstall the nuget all dll removed from project. Due to this, when using another package with same dependent package(compression.base), it will removed from project while uninstall the package. So, this is not a correct way.

How to refer main package and dependent package with same framework version while installing the nuget?

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "`msbuild /t:restore` should give better message when project is packages.config" (#7604) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Currently when you run `msbuild /t:restore` against a project that uses packages.config, you get the message:

> The project "MyProject" is not selected for building in solution configuration "Debug|Any CPU".

This makes me think that doing a `msbuild /t:build` should also give the same message, but in fact the project does build.

We should look into changing the reported message to say something like 

> The project "MyProject" uses packages.config which cannot be restored through msbuild.

Only report the "not selected for building in solution configuration" if a `/t:build` would report the same message.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Deprecation information omitted from search result" (#8719) at NuGet/Home
Closed issue "Error List pops up after use of package manager, even without messages and with option to show on build disabled" (#8691) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I did a simple repro…

1.	New WPF project
2.	Close Error List
3.	Uncheck “Always show Error List if build finishes with errors” under Projects and Solutions > General
4.	Manage NuGet Packages
5.	Switch to Browse
6.	Select a package and hit Install (I did it with Newtonsoft.Json)
7.	Accept any interim dialogs

Expected: Error List is still closed 
Current: Error List comes up with no messages in it. I would forgive it if there was some error, but since nothing technically went wrong and the user says they don’t want it… why should it post?

This was the root cause of this item: https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/idea/769040/error-list-window-is-always-shown.html

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Code files (.pp) in ContentFiles folder not added to consuming PackageReference project" (#8718) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I have create a multitarget nuget package which includes some code files (.pp) that need to be transformed and added to the consuming project. This works for projects using the 'packages.config' but not for projects using PackageReference.
I can see the transormed files somewhere hidden in '..\obj\Debug\net48\Nuget\CE11B4.....\...'. And they are actually somehow referenced in the project because I can use the code.

I would like the files to be added to the project so that the consumer can use and change them, like in the projects using 'packages.config'. Is this possible?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Get-Package: Stop abbreviations" (#8717) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Visual Studio Package Manager:
`PM> Get-Package`

```
Id                                  Versions                                 ProjectName                                                                                                                         
--                                  --------                                 -----------                                                                                           
Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore       {2.2.6}                                  XYZ.Server.WcfService                                                                                                               
Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.Ab... {2.2.6}                                  XYZ.Server.WcfService                                                                                                               
Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.An... {2.2.6}                                  XYZ.Server.WcfService                                                                                                               
Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.Re... {2.2.6}                                  XYZ.Server.WcfService                                                                                                               
Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.Sq... {2.2.6}                                  XYZ.Server.WcfService                                                                                                               
Microsoft.Extensions.Caching.Abs... {2.2.0}                                  XYZ.Server.WcfService                                                                                                               
Microsoft.Extensions.Caching.Memory {2.2.0}                                  XYZ.Server.WcfService                                                                                                               
Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration  {2.2.0}                                  XYZ.Server.WcfService                                                                                                               
Microsoft.Extensions.Configurati... {2.2.0}                                  XYZ.Server.WcfService                                                                                                               
Microsoft.Extensions.Configurati... {2.2.0}                                  XYZ.Server.WcfService                                                                                                               
Microsoft.Extensions.DependencyI... {2.2.0}                                  XYZ.Server.WcfService                                                                                                               
Microsoft.Extensions.DependencyI... {2.2.0}                                  XYZ.Server.WcfService                                                                                                               
Microsoft.Extensions.Logging        {2.2.0}                                  XYZ.Server.WcfService                                                                                                               
Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Abs... {2.2.0}                                  XYZ.Server.WcfService                                                                                                               
Microsoft.Extensions.Options        {2.2.0}                                  XYZ.Server.WcfService                                                                                                               
Microsoft.Extensions.Primitives     {2.2.0}                                  XYZ.Server.WcfService         
```

The problem: What's `Microsoft.Extensions.Configurati...`? `Microsoft.Extensions.DependencyInjection` or `Microsoft.Extensions.DependencyInjection.Abstractions`?

You might offer a switch to stop abbreviations.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Implement dotnet list package --vulnerable" (#8715) at NuGet/Home
Opened issue "Spec dotnet list package --vulnerable" (#8714) at NuGet/Home
Opened issue "NuGet 5.3 issues a warning for the dependency group when it is specified" (#8713) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet issues a warning NU5128 when csproj is specified as a target and nuspec with the same file name exists in the same directory as csproj file, and has the dependency group specified.

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe): NuGet.exe

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx): 5.3.0.6260

dotnet.exe --version (if appropriate): 3.0.100

VS version (if appropriate): Visual Studio 2019 Professional

OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)): win10 (17134)

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: 5.2

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Create new .Net Framework 4.5 library project/solution `test-project`
2. Import another library to this project using Nuget
3. Add dummy class file and build.
4. Run 'nuget.exe spec` in the same folder and `test-project.csproj`
5. Open `test-project.nuspec` created in the previous step and add the following dependency group under the `metadata` node
```
<dependencies>
  <group targetFramework=".NETFramework4.5">
    <dependency id="<imported library>" version="<library version>" />
  </group>
</dependencies>
```
6. pack the library using `NuGet.exe pack .\test-project.csproj`

Observe the NU5128 warning.

## Other suggested things

### Verbose Logs

NuGet Version: 5.3.0.6260
Attempting to build package from 'TestAutomation.EmsClient.csproj'.
MSBuild auto-detection: using msbuild version '16.3.1.50202' from 'C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2019\Professional\MSBuild\Current\bin'. Use option -MSBuildVersion to force nuget to use a specific version of MSBuild.
Packing files from '<file source (removed by reporter>'.
Using '<nuspec filename>.nuspec' for metadata.
Add file '<filepath>' to package as 'lib\net45\<filename>'
Add file '<filepath' to package as 'lib\net45\<filename>'
Found packages.config. Using packages listed as dependencies

Id: <packageId>
Version: 1.0.0
Authors: <author>
Description: <description>
Project Url: <project url>
Dependencies: <package dependencies>

Added file '[Content_Types].xml'.
Added file '_rels/.rels'.
Added file 'lib/net45/<filename>.dll'.
Added file 'lib/net45/<filename>.dll.config'.
Added file 'lib/net45/<filename>.pdb'.
Added file 'lib/net45/<filename>.xml'.
Added file 'package/services/metadata/core-properties/edcb844ffd994895a7b2834f44e52f9a.psmdcp'.
Added file '<specfilename>.nuspec'.

Successfully created package '<packagepath>'.
WARNING: NU5128: Some target frameworks declared in the dependencies group of the nuspec and the lib/ref folder do not have exact matches in the other location. Consult the list of actions below:
- Add a dependency group for .NETFramework4.5 to the nuspec

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Using OData to query NuGet.org repository is being deprecated" (#37) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
We introduced `V3 APIs` in early 2016. We have made continuous investments to make it more reliable, performant and secure. Going forward, we plan to bring all new features and improvements only to the newer `V3 APIs`. As part of this strategy, we are deprecating the usage of `OData` queries. Subsequently, we plan to **disable the `OData` queries starting Feb 5th, 2020**.

**Call to Action: Transition to V3 APIs**

Here are some resources to help you with the migration:
* [NuGet Server `V3 APIs` reference](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/switching-from-wcf-odata-to-web-api/)
* [Guide to transition from NuGet `V2 API` to `V3 API`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/guides/api/query-for-all-published-packages). 
* [Blog post: Switching from WCF OData to Web API](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/switching-from-wcf-odata-to-web-api/)

If you need further help in moving your use case to `V3 APIs`, do reach out to us at [support@nuget.org](mailto:support@nuget.org).

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Replace reference to codeplex issue numer 3072" (#36) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
This is copy of codeplex issue number 3072 as it is referenced inside code. I should do a PR shortly to address this one.

The place where it is referenced is RuntimeHelper.cs:150


---

We're hitting an issue with Microsoft.Bcl package where NuGet is adding a binding redirect for a binary that is considered part of the framework, this causes the application to crash because the binding redirect refers to assembly version that is not available at runtime.

@Repro:

1. Create a new Console Application targeting 4.5
2. Create a new Portable Library targeting .NET Framework 4.5, Silverlight 4, Windows Phone 7.5 and .NET for Windows Store apps
3. Add a reference to the portable library from the Console Application
4. Install the Microsoft.Bcl package (1.0.16-rc) to both projects

@Expected: No binding redirect for System.Runtime in the .NET Framework 4.5 project because a ___later version___ is part of the target framework (see C:\Program Files (x86)\Reference Assemblies\Microsoft\Framework\.NETFramework\v4.5\RedistList\FrameworkList.xml)
@Actual: Binding redirect

<dependentAssembly>
<assemblyIdentity name="System.Runtime" publicKeyToken="b03f5f7f11d50a3a" culture="neutral" />
<bindingRedirect oldVersion="0.0.0.0-1.5.11.0" newVersion="1.5.11.0" />
</dependentAssembly>


You can use the IVsFrameworkMultiTargeting to determine if a given assembly version is available as part of a given target framework.
Make sure when you fix this, that you only skip the binding redirect if ___a later or same version___ is available in the framework.  
2013-02-22

---

We'll do this in 2.4 release.  
2013-02-26

---

Is IVsFrameworkMultiTargeting.IsReferenceableInTargetFx the method I need to call? What should I pass to pwszAssemblySpec?  
2013-06-08

---

It's the full name of the assembly (mscorlib, Version=[version], PublicKeyToken=[token], Culture=[culture]). It can either contain all the information (key, version, etc), or just the simple name ("mscorlib")  
2013-06-10

---

So look like I can only check for the same version of the target framework. Can't check for a later version using this method, because I don't know what future versions will be.  
2013-06-12

---

That's fine. That's exactly the behavior we want. For example, System.Runtime didn't ship in 4.0, but did in 4.5. We still want a binding redirect generated for it in 4.0, but not for 4.5.  
2013-06-13

---

I followed the exact same steps above, but there's no binding redirect added to the Console Application. It's only added to the __Portable Library project__. Is that the bug?  
2013-06-13

---

The binding redirects added to the Portable Library project seems to come from the Microsoft.Bcl package itself (from the content folder's app.config.transform file). this looks like a non-bug.
2013-06-13

  
I'm chasing up the repro with Eric St. John. He walked through the code and figured out where it was broken.

It's the not the app.config.tranform, notice how the net45 content is empty, and hence no transforms. We also marked our transforms with a special marker that indicates that we added the redirects . The binding redirects we were seeing were not coming from us.  
2013-06-13

---

Are you seeing the binding redirects added to the Console Application or the Portable Library? I don't see binding redirect added to Console Application, only the Portable Library.  
2013-06-13

---

Yes I'm talking about the ConsoleApplication. The binding redirects in the portable library project are expected, and do not affect runtime behavior (as the app.config is ignored and not copied to the app project), and hence can't cause an application to crash.

I've found another repro (NuGet has really weird logic around when it decides to add binding redirects so it was hard to find a repro).

The repro is instead of using the Microsoft.Bcl package, install the Microsoft.Net.Http, 2.2.3-beta package. Make sure you are targeting __4.5__ from the ConsoleApplication and the exact platforms that I called out above for portable.  
2013-06-13

---

Also, the ConsoleApplication must be referencing the portable project before installing the package.  
2013-06-13

---

OK now I can repro  
2013-06-14

---

OK, I've got a fix now. It no longer adds the binding redirect for System.Runtime.dll, but still adds one for System.Net.Http.Primitives. I guess it's expected, right? Please confirm.

```
<assemblyBinding xmlns="urn:schemas-microsoft-com:asm.v1">
<dependentAssembly>
<assemblyIdentity name="System.Net.Http.Primitives" publicKeyToken="b03f5f7f11d50a3a" culture="neutral" />
<bindingRedirect oldVersion="0.0.0.0-4.2.3.0" newVersion="4.2.3.0" />
</dependentAssembly>
</assemblyBinding>
```  
2013-06-14

---


Yes that's correct. System.Net.Http.Primitives does not exist in the framework.  
2013-06-14

---

Fixed in changeset b8d515f6341193b970d2a9d837e580e762d2eb71  
2013-06-19

---

i get the same issue with my test project still, runtime being added... if i comment this out the tests run fine... if not i get exceptions thrown from json.net  
2013-08-09

---

(or i can change the version up to 4.0.0.0 or something and it works)  
2013-08-09

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Replace reference to codeplex issue numer 3072" (#36) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
This is copy of codeplex issue number 3072 as it is referenced inside code. I should do a PR shortly to address this one.

The place where it is referenced is RuntimeHelper.cs:150


---

We're hitting an issue with Microsoft.Bcl package where NuGet is adding a binding redirect for a binary that is considered part of the framework, this causes the application to crash because the binding redirect refers to assembly version that is not available at runtime.

@Repro:

1. Create a new Console Application targeting 4.5
2. Create a new Portable Library targeting .NET Framework 4.5, Silverlight 4, Windows Phone 7.5 and .NET for Windows Store apps
3. Add a reference to the portable library from the Console Application
4. Install the Microsoft.Bcl package (1.0.16-rc) to both projects

@Expected: No binding redirect for System.Runtime in the .NET Framework 4.5 project because a ___later version___ is part of the target framework (see C:\Program Files (x86)\Reference Assemblies\Microsoft\Framework\.NETFramework\v4.5\RedistList\FrameworkList.xml)
@Actual: Binding redirect

<dependentAssembly>
<assemblyIdentity name="System.Runtime" publicKeyToken="b03f5f7f11d50a3a" culture="neutral" />
<bindingRedirect oldVersion="0.0.0.0-1.5.11.0" newVersion="1.5.11.0" />
</dependentAssembly>


You can use the IVsFrameworkMultiTargeting to determine if a given assembly version is available as part of a given target framework.
Make sure when you fix this, that you only skip the binding redirect if ___a later or same version___ is available in the framework.  
2013-02-22

---

We'll do this in 2.4 release.  
2013-02-26

---

Is IVsFrameworkMultiTargeting.IsReferenceableInTargetFx the method I need to call? What should I pass to pwszAssemblySpec?  
2013-06-08

---

It's the full name of the assembly (mscorlib, Version=[version], PublicKeyToken=[token], Culture=[culture]). It can either contain all the information (key, version, etc), or just the simple name ("mscorlib")  
2013-06-10

---

So look like I can only check for the same version of the target framework. Can't check for a later version using this method, because I don't know what future versions will be.  
2013-06-12

---

That's fine. That's exactly the behavior we want. For example, System.Runtime didn't ship in 4.0, but did in 4.5. We still want a binding redirect generated for it in 4.0, but not for 4.5.  
2013-06-13

---

I followed the exact same steps above, but there's no binding redirect added to the Console Application. It's only added to the __Portable Library project__. Is that the bug?  
2013-06-13

---

The binding redirects added to the Portable Library project seems to come from the Microsoft.Bcl package itself (from the content folder's app.config.transform file). this looks like a non-bug.
2013-06-13

  
I'm chasing up the repro with Eric St. John. He walked through the code and figured out where it was broken.

It's the not the app.config.tranform, notice how the net45 content is empty, and hence no transforms. We also marked our transforms with a special marker that indicates that we added the redirects . The binding redirects we were seeing were not coming from us.  
2013-06-13

---

Are you seeing the binding redirects added to the Console Application or the Portable Library? I don't see binding redirect added to Console Application, only the Portable Library.  
2013-06-13

---

Yes I'm talking about the ConsoleApplication. The binding redirects in the portable library project are expected, and do not affect runtime behavior (as the app.config is ignored and not copied to the app project), and hence can't cause an application to crash.

I've found another repro (NuGet has really weird logic around when it decides to add binding redirects so it was hard to find a repro).

The repro is instead of using the Microsoft.Bcl package, install the Microsoft.Net.Http, 2.2.3-beta package. Make sure you are targeting __4.5__ from the ConsoleApplication and the exact platforms that I called out above for portable.  
2013-06-13

---

Also, the ConsoleApplication must be referencing the portable project before installing the package.  
2013-06-13

---

OK now I can repro  
2013-06-14

---

OK, I've got a fix now. It no longer adds the binding redirect for System.Runtime.dll, but still adds one for System.Net.Http.Primitives. I guess it's expected, right? Please confirm.

```
<assemblyBinding xmlns="urn:schemas-microsoft-com:asm.v1">
<dependentAssembly>
<assemblyIdentity name="System.Net.Http.Primitives" publicKeyToken="b03f5f7f11d50a3a" culture="neutral" />
<bindingRedirect oldVersion="0.0.0.0-4.2.3.0" newVersion="4.2.3.0" />
</dependentAssembly>
</assemblyBinding>
```  
2013-06-14

---


Yes that's correct. System.Net.Http.Primitives does not exist in the framework.  
2013-06-14

---

Fixed in changeset b8d515f6341193b970d2a9d837e580e762d2eb71  
2013-06-19

---

i get the same issue with my test project still, runtime being added... if i comment this out the tests run fine... if not i get exceptions thrown from json.net
